key_insight: GITIII is a lightweight, interpretable graph transformer that learns cell state and niche correlations via self-supervision to infer single-cell–level spatial interactions and quantify how neighbouring cells influence a receiver cell's gene expression.
problem_solved: Enables accurate, scalable inference of which nearby cells and niches drive gene expression changes in individual cells from spatial transcriptomics data while providing interpretable, per-cell influence scores.
method: Self-supervised graph transformer that models cells as nodes and spatial proximity/niche relations as edges to learn representations without heavy supervision.
Interpretable readouts (e.g., attention / influence scores) that quantify how much each neighbouring cell or niche contributes to a receiver cell's gene expression.
Lightweight architecture optimized for single-cell spatial data to scale across tissues while retaining biological interpretability.
impact: Provides AI/ML practitioners with a practical, interpretable model for linking spatial context to single-cell gene expression—useful for hypothesis generation, biomarker discovery, and integrating spatial datasets into downstream analyses.
visual_elements: Schematic tissue image with cells as graph nodes and edges showing neighbourhood connections (spatial layout).
Model architecture diagram: self-supervised graph transformer pipeline (input → encoder → attention/influence outputs).
Heatmap/overlay showing per-cell influence scores from neighbours mapped onto the tissue section.
Bar or violin plots comparing contribution magnitudes of different neighbour cell types to a receiver cell's expression.
paper_title: Inferring spatial single-cell-level interactions through interpreting cell state and niche correlations learned by self-supervised graph transformer
paper_authors: Xiao Xiao, Le Zhang, Hongyu Zhao, Zuoheng Wang
